docs.title: Welcome to GUM Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the documentation for GUM (General User Models), a powerful library for working with user models and simulations.

docs.title: What is GUM?
docs.text: GUM is a Python library designed to help developers and researchers work with user models and simulations. It provides a flexible and extensible framework for creating, managing, and analyzing user models.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Easy-to-use API for creating and managing user models
  • Support for various types of user simulations
  • Extensible architecture for custom model implementations
  • Comprehensive documentation and examples
  • Active community support

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
To get started with GUM, check out the following resources:

  • Installation Guide
  • Quick Start Tutorial
  • Basic Usage Guide

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: We welcome contributions! Please see our GitHub repository for more information on how to contribute.

docs.title: License
docs.text: GUM is released under the MIT License. See the LICENSE file for details.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide will help you install GUM and its dependencies.

docs.title: Using pip
docs.text:
The simplest way to install GUM is using pip:

pip install gum-ai

docs.title: From Source
docs.text:
To install from source:

  1. Clone the repository: 

    git clone https://github.com/yourusername/gum.git
cd gum

  2. Install the package: 

    pip install -e .

docs.title: Verifying Installation
docs.text:
To verify that GUM is installed correctly, you can run:

import gum
print(gum.__version__)

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text:
GUM has the following main dependencies: - numpy - pandas - scikit-learn - torch (optional, for deep learning features)

These will be automatically installed when you install GUM using pip.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
If you encounter any issues during installation:

  1. Make sure you have the latest version of pip: 

    pip install --upgrade pip

  2. If you're using a virtual environment, ensure it's activated before installation.

  3. For any specific error messages, please check our GitHub issues or create a new one.
